Precede BOSTON
Witnesses Report Seeing Bodies, Heavy Damage in Area of Noriega HQ
LEADS with 9 grafs with other witness' account; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Backalt, a ...'
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. attack in Panama City early today left many civilians dead in the streets and touched off a fire that leveled a slum area around a Panamanian Defense Forces stronghold, witnesses said. U.S. troops in helicopters warned townspeople in Panama's capital of the impending attack, assuring them by loudspeaker that the soldiers ``didn't have a problem with the government,'' said one witness. The witnesses spoke to reporters in Boston by telephone. ``They burned everything down,'' Manuel Backalt said in an interview from a Salvation Army office near the Defense Forces headquarters where he fled with his wife and three children. ``I see plenty people dead in the street.'' He said the bodies _ he did not know how many _ were mainly members of the dignity battalions, civilian paramilitary groups loyal to Noriega. Speaking through an interpreter, Rolando Diaz, 32, who also took refuge in the Salvation Army office, said there were warnings in the night of the coming attack. ``Before they started to bomb, they warned (those in the area of Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters) to come out,'' he said. ``They were shouting down over the PA system saying ... they didn't have a problem with the government.'' At that point residents of the slum area surrounding the headquarters, a section of mostly wooden homes, headed into the streets, he said. ``They came out when they heard the announcement, and American soliders led them to a neighborhood church,'' Diaz said. He said the American soldiers moved in as he was heading to the church. During the attack a fire began, destroying the area, he said. Backalt, a self-employed stove repairman, said he was sleeping when he heard gunfire. He said his house caught fire, and he and his family went out into the street. None of his family was injured. As they walked the streets, he said, they saw a helicopter crash. He said he didn't know if it was an American or Panamanian helicopter. Allan Wiltshire, head of the Salvation Army office, said Backalt was one of about 40 people near the office who were looking for assistance. He said it would be difficult to care for those displaced and injured in the attack. ``They want a place to stay because they are all burnt out. It's mounting up,'' he said. Wiltshire said pro-Noriega forces were commandeering cars throughout the morning from people driving during the attack. ``They say, `We're the police. We need your car,''' he said. His wife, Marjorie, said they saw several families scurrying about with their possessions. ``They were carrying TVs and their belongings on their heads,'' she said. ``We're just about to get some meals cooked so we can service them.'' The Salvation Army office is about two miles from Fort Amador, an American base, and is near the headquarters of the Panama Defense Forces. Wiltshire's daughter, Avonnie, said she was awakened by the sound of shooting. ``I thought it was firecrackers. We realized after that it was a lot of gunfire,'' she said. ``We tried to stay away from the windows and doors.'' The Wiltshires said the Armed Forces radio station broadcast warnings throughout the early morning, advising people stay indoors.
